conclusion: Use properties of ideal gas and relationships in the figure
Identify states and given data: State A: VA = V0, TA = T0, PA = P0; State B: VB = 2V0, TB = ?, PB = ?; State C: VC = ?, TC = ?, PC = ?
Use ideal gas law PV = nRT to relate states
For state A: PA VA = n R TA
For state B: PB VB = n R TB
AB is parallel to V axis, pressure is constant
PA = PB, therefore PA VA = PB VB
Substituting VA = V0 and VB = 2V0, PB = P0/2
PB = P0/2
Use relationship for state B using ideal gas law: PB VB = n R TB
Substituting PB = P0/2 and VB = 2V0, TB = P0 V0/n R
Since PA VA = n R TA and PA = P0 and VA = V0, n R = P0 V0/T0
Substitute n R = P0 V0/T0 into expression for TB, TB = T0
TB = 2T0
Extension line of BC is over the origin, volume is directly proportional to temperature
Implies VC/VB = TC/TB
From figure, VC = 1/2 V0 and VB = 2V0, VC/VB = 1/4
TC/TB = 1/4 and since TB = 2T0, TC = 1/2 T0
Determine pressure at state C using ideal gas law: PC VC = n R TC
Substituting VC = 1/2 V0 and TC = 1/2 T0, PC = P0
The temperature at state C is T0/2
